description: A five-slide presentation with key information about the American Robin.
title: All About the American Robin

slides.title: Introduction to the American Robin
slides.content: The American Robin (Turdus migratorius) is a migratory songbird and one of North America's most familiar and beloved birds. It's often considered a harbinger of spring and is known for its cheerful song and orange breast.

slides.title: Physical Characteristics
content: Adult robins have a distinctive orange-red breast, brown back, and white eye ring. They measure about 9-11 inches in length.
Young robins have spotted breasts and are often mistaken for different species until they mature.

slides.title: Diet and Foraging Behavior
content: Robins primarily eat earthworms, insects, and berries. They're famous for their 'worm dance' - running and stopping to listen for worms.
In winter, they switch to berries and fruits, often traveling in large flocks to find food sources.

slides.title: Migration and Habitat
content: Most robins migrate seasonally, though some northern populations are year-round residents.
They prefer open woodlands, gardens, parks, and lawns where they can forage easily on the ground.

slides.title: Cultural Significance
content: The American Robin is the state bird of Connecticut, Michigan, and Wisconsin.
Their spring arrival is celebrated as a sign of renewal, and they've been featured in literature, poetry, and folk songs.
